moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 g6: Seting up the King Indian's Defense.
moves.3. h3 Bg7 4. d5 d6 5. Qd4 O-O: This is the defensive setup for the King's Indian
moves.6. Qh4 Nbd7 7. g4 Ne5: Continuing to develop within the King's Indian while responding to the White Queen's position
moves.8. g5 Nxf3+ 9. exf3: If you notice, you will see that white hasn't castled yet and that his kingside pawn structure is completely destroyed. This opens up quite a few lines for my pieces
moves.9... Nh5 10. Nd2 e6 11. dxe6 Bxe6: All my pieces are developed and cooperate in a good way. My king is protected within the ideal King Indian setup and I can start preparing my attack
moves.12. b3 Bxa1: Crucial mistake for white. By not paying attention, white let me take one of his rook. The game is getting better and better for black.However, black still need to pay attention as the small slip can cost the game
Because I was a Rook ahead, I wanted here to exchange queens and move closer to an endgame.Didn't work out that well. 
In spite of losing a rook, white plays well and as you will see, causes me a few problems
moves.18. Bg5 Qg7 19. a4 h6 20. Be7 g5 21. Qb4: White is now ahead by 3 pawns, which is more or less a good compensation for the rook.White's overall position is still more or less in danger,but overall, white is causing me a few problems on the queen side.
The beginning of the end for white
